Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister stand by his election promise not to increase or introduce any new tax or levy during the life of this parliament?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I stand by my promises. Mr Albanese- Mr Speaker, with due respect: I would ask that the Prime Minister be asked to answer the question.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I believe the Prime Minister did give an answer. He was fairly quick off the mark. As I was giving the call believe he did give the answer. Transport: Port Export Capacity

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister advise the House of the progress the government is making to improve access to our shipping ports? Are there limitations on improved port efficiency and productivity?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Hinkler for his question. In this place yesterday I was asked a question by a member opposite which in effect said: why won't we show leadership in the areas of failure of leadership by the ments in the area of our ports? So today I thought it might be a good idea to work through the leadership that we are displaying in terms of boosting Australia's export performance and making it possible by providing the necessary land based infrastructure the areas that are our responsibility. Our freight task is anticipated to double between now and 2020. Our export figures are climbing very rapidly. Indeed, at the moment there is such a demand for coal by China that in recent times no less than 2Â½ per cent of the world's shipping fleet has been involved in moving coal from the Hunter Valley to China alone. In fact, Australia delivers some 12 per cent of the world's total shipping task. The market for commodities at the moment being very strong, it is certainly providing us with a clear indication of what is needed in the future. I have spoken many times in here about one area where we have provided leadership, and it is an area where successive Labor governments said that not only could they not lead but that it could not be done in the Australian context: the waterfront. We have got an average I movement of containers now across our five major ports of 28.2 containers per hour, when the Labor Party said we could not get above 15. I would have thought that was a pretty dramatic example of leadership. More than that, can I make this point in terms of our responsibilities. The interfacing between road, rail and ports in this nation is extraordinarily significant, and it has not been done well enough. I want to say that we are moving to fix it very quickly. If you take New South Wales alone, the Australian Rail Track Corporation has commenced a $260 million rail infrastructure program in the Hunter Valley to fix up inadequacies left behind by a state government that would not state govern- properly invest. In Victoria, you have got the improved road and rail links where, under AusLink, $110 million is being provided into the Dynon intermodal precinct and the Port of Melbourne, and $40 million is being proin vided for a railway line between Tottenham and Footscray to reduce congestion. In Sydney you have got $110 million to improve rail access to the Port of Botany, and in Western Australia $14 million is being provided for a new rail loop to Fremantle port, and new road access to the port, and that project is already under way. These are the measures needed, and we are providing the resources, the planning and the leadership to make them happen. But the point that ought to be noted is that the question yesterday was in relation to Queensland. The House might like to know that the one state in Australia that has refused to negotiate with the Australian Rail Track Corporation, owned by us, to allow for proper leasing arrangements, access to their ports and upgrading under AusLink is Queensland-the Beattie government. They cannot do it themselves, and they want to stand in the way of the Australian government facilitating their exports. The member for Perth ought to go back to the Queensland government instead of asking us to provide the leadership that these Labor states will not provide and talk to them about negotiating sensibly with the Australian Rail Track Corporation. Education: Vocational and Technical Education

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister stand by his election promise that no fees will be charged at the government's new technical colleges?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen suggestions that the states need assistance to abolish their inefficient and harmful state taxes? Are there any other proposals?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Braddon for his question. I can inform the House that, when the GST was introduced, it was introduced pursuant to an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states which provided that the states got all GST revenue. The Commonwealth entered into an agreement to say that, if the GST revenue did not get up to the amount that the states would have got under the old system, the Commonwealth would make up the difference. Let me inform the House that, in the current financial year of 2004-05, every state will be in front of the guaranteed amount; no state will require a top-up; and, on the latest estimates, the cumulative windfall over and above the guaranteed amount which the states will receive in 2004-05 is $2,198 million-for one year. A government member-How much?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: $2,198 million. The New South Wales government will receive from the GST, in excess of the guaranteed minimum amount, $269 million-and this is for just one year. The Victorian government will receive, over and above the guaranteed minimum amount, $360 million in 2004-05. And-get a load of this-the Queensland government will receive, in excess of the guaranteed minimum amount, $796 million in 2004-05. It was a condition of that agreement that, in return for that growth in the revenue base, the states would abolish their indirect taxes. Bed taxes have already been abolished, stamp duties on marketable securities have already been abolished, financial institutions duty has already been abolished, and we have secured the agreement of the states to abolish the bank account debits tax as from 1 July 2005. But plainly, with this windfall over and above the guaranteed amount, the states could go further in abolishing inefficient indirect taxes. We will be going to the intergovernmental council in March next year with proposals to use those revenue windfalls for the abolition of further taxes, which was always the intention of the new federal financial relations. Matters which will be considered are stamp duties on non-residential conveyances, on marketable securities, on leases, on mortgages, on credit arrangements and on cheques, bills of exchange and promissory notes. There is no need to give the states additional windfalls to keep them to the agreement that has been entered into. The states are, in this year alone, enjoying a windfall over $2.9 billion. Right across the forward estimates they will continue to enjoy those windfalls. We, the Commonwealth, will be arguing strenuously that those revenues be used to reduce indirect state taxes. Education: Vocational and Technical Education

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Has the minister seen yesterday's Australian Financial Review where he is reported as saying that students attending the Howard government's new technical colleges are to be charged fees? Doesn't this directly contradict the Prime Minister's election promise that no fees would be charged at these technical colleges? Doesn't the minister for vocational education's fee announcement reveal that the Prime Minister misled Australians during that campaign, and isn't this another broken election promise?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am delighted to receive this question from the member for Jagajaga, in whose electorate there has been a 255 per cent increase in the number of new apprentices during the time she has been a member-some 1,749 people. When you factor that into the swing against her at the last election, that is about every one of them not voting for her. The Australian technical colleges are going to be centres of excellence. They will be run autonomously by their principal. They will be governed by a board led by industry. They will operate in a very similar way to existing government and non-government schools. But, to be eligible for Australian government funding, Australian technical colleges must meet the same funding requirements as all other schools. Only schools that are not for profit are eligible for Commonwealth funding. Let me be very clear: no of additional fees will be charged in respect of the Australian technical colleges, and the article that she talks about makes that point. Of course, it may well be that there are in existing schools a range of fees and charges and, depending on the consortia which are brought together, some costs already there for students today. But the surprising part is the indignity from those opposite today. It was on 8 July 2003 that my esteemed colleague the minister for education wrote to Premier Carr in New South Wales and asked the Leader of the Opposition to co-sign a letter-he actually asked the Leader of the Opposition to co-sign a letter-protesting a 300 per cent increase in fees. If the member for Jagajaga's quote from the Australian Financial Review yesterday is correct-she said that, if students have to pay to attend colleges, it would aggravate the skills shortage-where was the press release when the New South Wales government cranked it up 300 per cent? Where was the press release when in Victoria fees rose by 25 per cent at TAFE? Where was the press release when in South Australia the fees went up by 50 per cent? Those opposite are on this curious mission to stop this government dealing with the urgent skills shortage in this country. They are on this curious mission to deny the workers of Australia the opportunity for their sons and their daughters to follow in their footsteps and to be well placed to lead Australia into a very, very successful and strong economic future. Trade: Japan

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House of recent developments in Australia's trading relationship with Japan?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Maranoa for his question. The member for Maranoa, representing a significant proportion of Queensland, recognises the importance of the trading relationship that we enjoy with Japan. That trading relationship is probably one of the most significant and enduring in East Asia. Japan has long been our largest export destination. In 2003-04 our total trade in goods and services with Japan was worth $41.2 billion. Of that, Australia's exports to Japan were worth $23.1 billion. That covered a range of goods and services. Japan is the single most important market for the Australian resource commodity export sector, and it is our largest customer for LNG. In 2002-03 our resource exports to Japan were worth $14 billion. Since 1996, we have delivered almost 7.5 million tonnes of LNG per annum into that market out of the North West Shelf in Western Australia. I am delighted to inform the House-and I know the member for Maranoa will be particularly interested in this statistic-that tralia now supplies 91 per cent of Japan's imported beef, valued at over $1 billion. It is going to be about 360,000 tonnes this year. Ninety-one per cent of that market is dominated by Australian product, and that is largely due to the effort of the organisations that promote our exports into that part of the world. Goods exports to Japan rose 25 per cent in the three-quarters of the year until September quarter this year, which is a significant increase in the exports into this most important market. But when we are contemplating these important statistics and what has been achieved, it is incumbent upon us to recognise that that strong trading relationship that we have with Japan started many decades ago. It was actually instigated over 50 years ago by Black Jack MCEwen, who looked at the important rise in industrialisation in Japan. We should recognise that. I am pleased to say that this coalition government, now in its fourth term, has continued delivering Australian exporters extra access into this very important market. Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House how government measures are improving workplace relations in the the building industry, particularly in Western Australia?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Stirling for his question. I was delighted to be able to spend some time with him at a small business forum I attended in Perth in his electorate. What we have in Western Australia, where the honourable member for Stirling is from, is a massive increase in industrial disputation under the Gallop government. In 2001, the rate of industrial disputes in Western Australia was 32 working days per thousand employees. By the end of 2003-two years later-that rate had trebled to 97 working days lost per thousand employees. This is the highest rate of any state in Australia, and it is almost double the national average of 53. What we see is the Gallop government allowing militant unions in Western Australia to run amok. Justice Cole in his inquiry into the building and construction industry found that this was the case. He said in his report that the Western Australian construction industry is: ... marred by unlawful and inappropriate conduct ... Fear intimidation and coercion are commonplace. Contractors, subcontractors, and workers face this culture continuously. What we see under the Gallop government and its so-called reforms of industrial relations is a clear failure for the workers and employers in that state. As a result of that, workers and employers are voting with their feet and fleeing from the state system to the federal system. In Western Australia we have seen a massive 277 per cent growth in Australian workplace agreements between 2001-02 and 2002-03. Indeed, over 100,000 Australian workplace agreements have been lodged in Western Australia in just the last two years. That is workers in Western Australia fleeing from the state industrial system, and the militancy which is allowed there, into the federal system. This impressive movement to the federal system shows how regressive the current Western Australian scheme is. This lack of control of militant unions is a threat to the Western Australian economy. It is a particular threat where we see the massive growth in AWAs in the resources sector. This sector contributes something like one-quarter of the total gross product of the state of Western Australia. The mineral and petroleum industries contribute to almost one in five jobs in Western Australia and make up 80 per cent of the state's exports. This is the sector which is most in jeopardy from the regressive workplace relations system in Western Australia. I call upon the Western Australian state government to abandon this regressive system and adopt the much more progressive system of the Howard government. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the minister confirm that she wrote a letter to me dated 2 December 2004 stating that she had recently approved funding for the Horse Australia 2005 project through the Regional Partnerships program? Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-As parliamentary secretary I advised members on their projects, and the project in Capricornia was one that was widely supported by the member for Capricornia and her constituents. I make no apology for this government investing wisely and soundly in rural and regional Australia. Health: Immunisation

Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister explain to the House how the government is building on its strong childhood immunisation record?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the new member for Wakefield for his question and I congratulate him on his rather splendid arrival in this House. I can tell the House that since 1990 childhood immunisation rates have increased from about 50 per cent to over 90 per cent. Government spending on vaccination has increased from just $13 million in 1996 to $254 million in the current financial year. From 1 January all newborns will be eligible for pneumococcal vaccination and there will be a catch-up program for children born after 1 January 2003. In 2002 invasive pneumococcal disease affected some 761 Australian children, with nine deaths. That is what the government's program is designed to combat. The Chief Medical Officer has already written to parents reminding them of the catch-up program. This week GPs have been alerted to the start of the pneumococcal vaccination program. The parents of newborns should receive information about pneumococcal vaccination before their babies leave hospital, during home visits from community health care nurses and at their children's first check-up. The government is determined to ensure that there is a wide take-up of this important new vaccination program. This government does not just talk about Medicare; it invests the money that is necessary to make a good health system even better. Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Given the minister wrote to the member for Capricornia on 2 December informing her of funding of $220,000 for the Horse Australia 2005 project, will the minister now inform the House when she approved this grant under the Regional Partnerships program? Minister, under what authority was this approval made, given that you were sworn in as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs five weeks earlier, on 26 October? Mr Abbott- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under the ruling that you made earlier, and under the practices and procedures of this House, it is quite clear that a minister cannot be questioned in this House on matters for which he or she was responsible as a parliamentary secretary. This question is clearly out of order. Mr Latham- Mr Speaker, on the point of order and to clarify the chronology: we are talking about a letter written by the Hon. DeAnne Kelly to Kirsten Livermore, the member for Capricornia, dated 2 December-that is, last Thursday-and received on 6 December. That is fully within the remit and time which De-Anne Kelly has been a minister-sworn in on 26 October. It is perfectly legitimate for the opposition to ask the question that most people would be asking: why is the minister making these grants?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat and I will rule on the point of order. The question does place the chair in a slightly difficult position. But, thinking about it, I believe that the point of order from the Leader of the House will be upheld. Mr Kelvin Thomson- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order as to your ruling. The purpose of question time is to enable the opposition to bring ministers to account. Our very question here is that the minister has exceeded her authority. You cannot rule that she is not obliged to answer questions on the basis that she has exceeded her authority.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The ruling is based, very simply, on what I said in my statement yesterday; that is, that a parliamentary secretary is not to be held responsible to answer questions. The point is that the minister is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and can be questioned on matters relating to her role as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. NA

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: I move: That the ruling be dissented from.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Is it in writing?

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Yes, it is in writing and signed. Mr Speaker, it is plainly absurd to deny the opposition the opportunity to question De-Anne Kelly about matters that she has discharged as a minister of the Crown. It is absolutely absurd to deny us the chance to question her on why she has sent to Kirsten Livermore, the member for Capricornia, a letter dated 2 December which reads as follows: Dear Ms Livermore I have recently approved funding under Regional Partnerships for Horse Australia Rockhampton Association Inc for the Horse Australia 2005 project in your electorate. Regional Partnerships is an Australian Government initiative that makes it simpler for communities to apply for Australian Government support for regional development projects. Regional Partnerships is administered by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. Yours sincerely De-Anne Kelly This is on a letterhead that reads, âDe-Anne Kelly, Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services'. Mr Speaker, respectfully, every single Australian taxpayer would want to know why the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, five weeks after she has been sworn into that position, is dispensing money for another department-the Department of Transport and Regional Services. What is going on with the Howard government? What is going to be the next practice? We will have the minister for education purchasing aircraft carriers. We will have the minister for health purchasing tanks and other military equipment.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Mr Speaker, a glass of water is not a point of order. Your ruling must be dissented from. It is plainly absurd to allow a minister to avoid parliamentary scrutiny when, just moments ago in the House, she admitted to the member for Capricornia that this signature here is hers, that this letter is hers and that five weeks after she was sworn in as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs she is still dispensing the pork. I believe this raises important legal and constitutional questions. Under what legal authority does a minister for veterans' affairs dispense money from another department? You thought I had something to do with veterans' affairs but-surprise, surprise-I am here to announce a funding project in your electorate for a different department under a totally different program'? They might have sorted it out over there, but the Australian peopleMr Abbott- Mr Speaker, I am reluctant to interrupt the Leader of the Opposition, but I do say to assist him and, I hope, to assist the House that my understanding is that the parliamentary secretary does have an answer and she is prepared to give it.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Mr Speaker, that was the Clayton's point of order, where the Leader of the House knows that you have made a mistake and knows that this motion of dissent should be carried, but he will not admit it. is now trying to slide out from under the motion by saying, âShe is going to come up to the dispatch box under an unknown standing order of the House to try and give the answer.' How about the government supports the dissent motion, and then makes the minister give the answer, because this Speaker has stuffed it up? Mrs Bronwyn Bishop- Mr Speaker, I simply wanted to make the point of order that, understanding order 91 dealing with disorderly conduct, the Leader of the Opposition is guilty of disorderly conduct by reflecting on your earlier ruling and as such should be ruled out of order.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: My word I am reflecting on the ruling-so much so that I am moving a motion of dissent from the ruling! My word I am reflecting it! I am reflecting on the principle of Westminster accountability. What the Speaker is trying to say to this House is this: if the minister for education authorises the purchase of tanks and aircraft carriers, we cannot ask questions about it. He may have no legal authority and no constitutional authority with which to make that purchase under the orders that have been issued by the Governor General and, even though he is a minister of the Crown, we cannot ask the question. Of course we should be able to ask the question, just as we want to ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs under what legal authority, under what remit, under what constitutional provision she is dispensing money from another department? If she had written to the member for Capricornia saying, âListen, I am the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and you have got some worthy RSL projects in your electorate and we are going to fund them with this grant,' that would be standard He practice. No-one would blink an eyelid. But surely it is unprecedented in our time in this House to have a minister, on the letterhead of a parliamentary secretary to another minister for which she has no responsibility, announcing the grant. I think it is highly likely that she has written these letters to other people associated with the Horse Australia 2005 project. I would expect that, if she is notifying the member for Capricornia, she would also be notifying the local ACC, and she would be notifying the proponents, Horse Australia Rockhampton Association, of the fact they have just been awarded $220,000. For the past week and a half in the House, we have been raising legitimate questions about the regional pork rorts; we have been raising legitimate questions about the SONA secret slush fund. Surely it gets to the point of asking a legitimate question, under extraordinary circumstances, as to how Minister Kelly and Veterans' Affairs are still dispensing the pork and as to how Minister Kelly is still rolling out the barrel and dispensing money from someone else's department. I put it to you that the authority issued by the Governor General on 26 October

Title: DISSENT FROM RULING

Reluctant though I am to interrupt this tirade, the fact is that a dissent debate has to stick strictly to the terms of the dissent. The Leader of the Opposition is now ranging far and wide and making all sorts of allegations against the former parliamentary secretary, and he should not be allowed to do so.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: I ask the Leader of the Opposition to come back to the motion before the chair.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Mr Speaker, I am coming back to the order issued by the Governor General on 26 October which gave De-Anne Kelly authority to issue funding as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. This order did not make her the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. One must question the legality of what she is doing-and that is a legitimate question to raise in this House. But it also raises the issue of why, just moments ago, you ruled it in order when the member for Capricornia got to her feet and asked: Can the minister confirm that she wrote a letter me dated 2 December 2004 stating that she had recently approved funding for the Horse Australia 2005 project through the Regional Partnerships program? Can the minister confirm that she used her letterhead as the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services? Mr Speaker, you ruled that in order. You allowed the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to answer that question. Why, just moments ago, did you allow the member for Capricornia to ask the question about the letter on 2 December issuing the grant in the electorate of Capricornia but you do not allow me to ask a question on the same subject, concerning the same letter, the same grant, the same minister, the same lack of authority and the same lack of legality for what she is doing? I asked: given that the minister wrote to the member for Capricornia on 2 December-same letter, same issue-informing her of funding of $220,000 for the Horse Australia 2005 project, will the minister inform the House when she approved this grant? Fair enough, she has written in the letter that she recently approved it. If that was any time in the last five weeks, since De-Anne Kelly has been the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the public-the people who work hard to pay their taxes in this country-would want to know under what legal authority she is dispensing, approving and notifying a grant in someone else's department. That is a perfectly legitimate question. You ruled in order the question from the member for Capricornia. You will not allow me to ask a similar question on the same subject, the same grant, the same minister, the same perversion of process. I went on to ask: under what authority was this approval made, given that DeAnne Kelly was sworn in as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs five weeks earlier, on 26 October? It is curious indeed-some would say exto traordinary-that this has happened. But the whole purpose of question time is for the opposition to ask questions to hold the executive government to account. Mr Speaker, your role is to defend the right of members to seek information in areas where the ministers have acted. This minister has acted in a way that is extraordinary and perhaps unprecedented. Surely the Australian people have the right to know about that, just as they have the right to know about the secret slush fund of SONA, and the right to know how the regional pork-rorts have been dispensed. They have the right, in this parliament, to know about the rorting of different projects. We have not received the answers from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, but surely we should now get an answer from Minister Kelly. Surely Minister Kelly should concede that this dissent motion should be carried. We have half a concession by the Leader of the House that the dissent motion should be carried. He wants Minister Kelly to answer the question, but he will not allow a majority vote on the dissent motion. Mr Speaker, he is basically saying that he has no confidence in you, but he is trying to hide embarrassment, just as he did last week when he had to apologise to you in the debate on a separate dissent motion. We had the unprecedented action of the Leader of the House apologising to the Speaker for letting him dangle in the breeze, to the embarrassment of the House. I would have thought that it was time for the Leader of the House to be honest about it and say, âWhoops: a second apology'-a second time where the government should have said up front: âLet the dissent motion go through. The Speaker has got it wrong. Let the minister give her answer to the House.' Mr Speaker, this is our second dissent motion in a fortnight. We are doing this because we believe it is true to the proper standards of accountability in this House. We believe it is consistent with your promise to the House to be firm but fair. We have had the member for Capricornia asking a question which was perfectly legitimate. Imagine her surprise as the local representative, and the surprise of her staff, to get a letter from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs dispensing money from someone else's department. They must have been very surprised about it-Christmas had come early. All of a sudden it was raining money in the seat of Capricornia-out of other departments. How did it happen? The member for Capricornia has raised the question in the House. The minister strode up to the dispatch box, as bold as brass, to say, âYep, it's my letter, that's my signature, and I have notified it out'-and we assume that she has notified it out to the ACC and the proponents of the grant, Horse Australia 2005. Mr Speaker, given that you allowed that question, surely it is in order for me to ask a question on the same issue. We now have the government and Mr Abbott saying that they want the minister to answer the question; they are conceding that the question is in the order. The government backbenchers are rich and red with embarrassment about the way the Speaker is discharging his duties, because they all know the fundamental truth about this Speaker and how he got the job. They all know the fundamental truth that, when the former member for Wakefield, Mr Andrew, announced his impending retirement some 12 months ago, there was intense lobbying. The member for Mackellar, the member for Cook and the member for Wannon were all lobbying the backbenchers and saying, âIf we get back in, I want to be the Speaker'. At the end of every single question timeMr Abbott-On the point of order, Mr Speaker: the Leader of the Opposition is simply indulging himself here and he should be brought back to the strict terms of the dissent.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: The honourable the Leader of the Opposition will come back to the motion before the chair.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Having got the job, Mr Speaker, you said that you would be firm but fair, but we see no fairness. We just see the firmness of trying to cover up for ministers time after time. We saw it last week. We saw the apology from Mr Abbott, the Leader of the House, and today his concession, effectively, that the dissent motion is valid-it should be carried-and the minister should answer the question that was ruled out of order. How can he nod and say that he wants the minister to answer if the Speaker has already ruled it out of order? There is no mechanism available to the opposition other than a dissent motion, given the fact that our valid question has been ruled out of order by the Speaker. It is absolutely fundamental to the principles of Westminster accountability that the opposition is entitled to raise concerns about a minister having exceeded his or her authority. We are not pretending that this is a under the Department of Veterans' Affairswe are not saying that at all. The minister has herself conceded that this is a grant under the Department of Transport and Regional Services. If our questions are to be ruled out of order on the basis of this particular ruling, then how can we ever ask questions of ministers who have exceeded their ministerial authority? Mr Speaker, unfortunately you are writing a blank cheque for ministers to go and do anything-for ministers to get outside their legal and constitutional authority, run amok in the Public Service, grab a hold of money, throw it out in any old electorate, do whatever they like in the administration of government and then say in the House of Representatives that no-one can ever ask them a question about it. We cannot have a blank cheque for ministers to do whatever they like, exceeding their ministerial authority willy-nilly, dispensing money from someone else's department, sending out letters, sending out cheques and rolling out the porkbarrel without accountability in the House of Representatives. I cannot think of a worse precedent for the accountability of ministers in this House than to say, âYeah, sure, they can go and exceed their ministerial authority and spend money in someone else's department, but anyone on the opposition side who dares to ask a question about it is out of order-you're gone.' Mr Speaker, it is just nonsensical. It is absurd. Every single Australian taxpayer would want to know the legitimate answer, if there is one, to our legitimate question. So why not concede the point that the dissent motion is entirely valid. This is the most classic example of a minister exceeding their authoritya Minister for Veterans' Affairs advising of her decision to dispense grants from the Regional Partnerships program, which is adgrant ministered by another department and another minister. We may well get the answer; it looks like we will-she is sitting there ready to go. But, Mr Speaker, I am arguing this dissent motion and seeing it right through on the vital precedent that, if a minister gets outside the law-a minister gets outside the Constitution; a minister gets outside his or her legal authority-then surely the House of Representatives, the people's house, must have the capacity to ask questions about that. If we allow this precedent to pass-if the government knocks off the dissent motion-it will be a black day on this parliament. It will be a black day on the principles of ministerial accountability. I can think of scandals and controversies in the past where former Speakers, former elders in this House, would be shaking their heads that they would not have been allowed to ask questions about a minister exceeding his or her authority. Mr Speaker, you should be better than that. You should recognise, despite your election promises to the backbench to be tough on us, that this question must be asked, it must be ruled in order and this minister must be accountable to the House of Representatives.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Mr Speaker, I second the motion and I concur with the Leader of the Opposition. This is a shameful day on which you have made a ruling which would protect the worse forms of corruption in government and leave them unaccountable to the House of Representatives. Let us be very clear about what has happened here, Mr Speaker: this minister has sent a letter to the member for Capricornia dated 2 December. She only had two capacities on 2 December: she was the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and she was the private person Mrs De-Anne Kelly. Is anybody in this House contending that she sent that letter in her private capacity as a citizen of Australia? No, no-one is because no-one could. The only other capacity she had on that day, apart from her truly private capacity, was as a minister in this place-a Minister for Veterans' Affairs-and we are seeking to ask her questions about that. The effect of the ruling you have made, Mr Speaker, is in direct contradiction to the standing orders. You could not get a clearer contradiction to the standing orders. If I could take you to standing order 98(c): A Minister can only be questioned on the following matters, for which he or she is responsible or officially connected: (i) public affairs; Are you suggesting her sending a letter to the member for Capricornia about the dispersal of government money is not public affairs? Well, was is it? Coming out of her bank account, is it? Is that where the money came from? It must be public affairs and it is public affairs. The question ought to be allowed and the ruling is wrong. But of even more concern, you allowed the first question from the member for Capricornia and you only ruled this way after a point of order by the Leader of the House. Can I remind you, Mr Speaker, I was without joy at this dispatch box last week in a dissent motion where, when the Leader of the House replied, he conceded that he, the government, had put you in a difficult position by the framing of a question to the minister for education and what had flowed from the framing of that question. Mr Speaker, can I remind you that just less than a short week ago we were in this very same place courtesy of the antics and tactics of the Leader of the House. You have only ruled this way on the urging of the Leader of the House, and in his urging he is directly wrong-directly in contradiction of the standing orders; directly wrong in terms of proper accountability to this House; directly wrong in any understanding of the proper dispersal of taxpayer's funds. The Leader of the House ought to have been told when he sought this ruling from you that it was wrong and you were not going to give it. I would ask you to reflect, Mr Speaker, on the fact that within less than a week we are back to the same place, with a dissent motion following a bad ruling, which conduct by the Leader of the House led to. I would ask you to reflect, Mr Speaker, when you do have time to reflect on this debate, on whether that is going to be the course of dealing in this House. Because, if it is going to be the course of dealing in this House, if the Leader of the House is going to rise and seek to have you make these rulings, then you will always be in this position. The problem for you, Mr Speaker, is that just after he has put you in this position he gives you up. He is not even a loyal friend, not even an ally in your time of need, because what he has effectively done in respect of your rulingMr Causley- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member for Lalor is now reflecting on the chair. She should be settling the dissent motion and clearly stating where they are dissenting from the ruling of the chair.

Title: DISSENT FROM RULING

Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Mr Speaker, I am just indicating that I am a better friend of yours than the Leader of the House is, because halfway through this dissent motion, having made the point of order that led us to this, the Leader of the House has now given you up and has basically sought to get out from under this dissent motion. He knows that what he should really do, given the view he has formed, is direct government members to vote for this dissent motion, but he knows inevitably where that leads. So now we are going through the farce where you, Mr Speaker, ruled out of order the Leader of the Opposition's question, we are going to presumably have an unsuccessful dissent motion on it and then the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is going to get up and answer the question. That is what is going to happen in this place now. That is exactly what is going to happen in this place. You ruled out of order the Leader of the Opposition's question, on the urging of the Leader of the House; we have moved a motion of dissent on your ruling; the government is going to use its numbers to vote down that dissent; and then she is going to get up and answer the question. Do you think that is how the House of Representatives should run, Mr Speaker, or would it have been better to have ruled against the Leader of the House when he made the point of order? Would it have been better to do that, Mr Speaker? That is where we are-in a grand absurdity which would be a grand absurdity of humorous proportions if it were not about such a serious issue. What we have here on the face of it is a minister of the Howard government, a minister of the Crown, making arrangements in relation to taxpayers' money which are not within her portfolio area. That is what this is about. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs is just that-the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. And, presumably, as Minister for Veterans' Affairs she gets to disburse funds in the veterans' affairs portfolio. What she does not get to do is disburse funds in other portfolios, and that is what she has purported to do and that is what we are asking about and that is why our question is in order. The examples that the Leader of the Opposition gave are absolutely right. Are you suggesting through this ruling, Mr Speaker, that the best way of hiding inappropriate use of taxpayers' funds in government is for people to do it outside their portfolio? Would the minister for immigration or the Attorney General be protected from questioning in this place if they disbursed funds in the health portfolio? Would that protect the minister from questioning? Would it protect the minister for health from questioning if he purported to disburse funds in the education portfolio? Would that actually protect him from questioning? That is the essence of this dissent motion. I know it is hard for you to follow

Title: DISSENT FROM RULING

We are now in circumstances where, when we seek to ask questions on these issues, you presumably-if this dissent motion is not upheld-will continue to rule them out of order, Mr Speaker. So apparently the only snippets of information we are ever going to get are the ones that the government is prepared to volunteer. Apparently it is prepared to volunteer a snippet of information today, as we found out mid-dissent motion. What sort of position is that to put the House of Representatives in-where, if a government volunteers a piece of information, that is okay, but, if in the proper exercise of our democratic duty as members of the House of Representatives and most particularly as members of the opposition we seek to question and hold government ministers to account on those snippets of information, that further questioning will be ruled out of order? Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING
text: Yes, Mr Speaker. On the motion of dissent on the ruling that you made today, I am making what I think is the very clear point that the effect of your ruling is that there could be acres of government information-filing cabinets full of documents; computers with hard disks in overload, there is so much information stored on them-that we would never be able to ask about in this House of Representatives. That is the effect of your ruling today, because all the government needs to do to protect itself from questioning is to get a non-portfolio minister to deal with the matter. In the face of that ruling, is that not what you would do if you wanted to have a bit of a dodgy grants program, if you wanted to hand out a little bit of pork here or if you wanted to protect something from public scrutiny? With this ruling on the books, next time would you not say to yourself: âIf I do that directly, I will be subject to questioning about it. If I hand it to the minister next to me, then I will not be subject to questioning about it.' That is where we are driving to with the current ruling, and why it must be dissented from. It is wrong, it is bad, it is offensive in the spirit of holding the executive government to account and it is wholly outside the standing orders. These standing orders do not say that you can only come in here and ask a minister about the minutiae of their portfolio. These standing orders use the terminology âpublic affairs'. Why do the standing orders use the terminology âpublic affairs'? Because the standing orders understand that once you are sworn in as a minister of the Crown you have only two personalities: your genuinely private personality at home, where you are doing things as a private citizen, and everything else is your public personality. You are entitled to be questioned about that âeverything else'. Mr Speaker, by this ruling you have clearly prevented us from questioning the Minister for Veterans' Affairs about something she did in an official capacity. She wrote on government letterhead to a member of the House of Representatives about the disbursal of funds. How could you get more official than that-government letterhead to a member of the House of Representatives about the disbursal of funds? The effect of this ruling is to prevent us from asking about the disbursal of that money. It is not the government's money; it is everybody's money. It is taxpayers' money. The purpose of question time is to hold the government to account on these questions. I conclude where I began, by saying that this is a shameful day and this is a completely incorrect ruling. It had to be dissented from because it will lead to the protection of all sorts of corruption in government if it is allowed to stand-particularly if it is allowed to stand unchallenged. It is clearly a wrong ruling, because it is actually contradictory to your first ruling today. Through your conduct in calling the minister and allowing her to answer, you ruled that that question to the minister was in order. We have only ended up in this absurdity because of the intervention of the Leader of the House. I say to you, Mr Speaker: just like last week he has led you into error. This is not bringing any credit to the office of Speaker or, indeed, to the House of Representatives-and is certainly not bringing any credit to the shameful conduct of the Howard government.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: DISSENT FROM RULING

Your ruling was absolutely and completely correct and wholly in accordance with the customs, practices and standing orders of this House. Let us be very clear about what happened here. The Leader of the Opposition asked a question of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs relating to her responsibilities as a parliamentary secretary. It is a clear rule of this House that you cannot question parliamentary secretaries in this chamber. You cannot ask a minister-in this case the Minister for Veterans' Affairs-about what she did when she was a parliamentary secretary. That is a clear principle of this House. Mr Speaker, your ruling is entirely in accordance with the standing orders, customs, traditions and practices of this House. We have heard some talk opposite about your earlier ruling. Let me make it clear: you have made but one ruling today. This was the correct ruling you made in response to a point of order taken after the Leader of the Opposition asked a question which was clearly out of order. No point of order was taken in respect of the first question. You made no ruling in respect of the first question. Your ruling is absolutely right and deserves more respect from members opposite, who know that it is a long tradition of this House-confirmed as recently as yesterday in your statement from the chair-that ministers can only be questioned about that for which they have responsibility as ministers. Ministers cannot be questioned about that for which they formerly had responsibility as parliamentary secretaries. It is a very clear point. Your ruling is absolutely, completely correct. Mr Speaker, your ruling was right, but we are not a cruel government. We are not brutal, even towards a demoralised opposition and even towards an opposition led by Mr Twenty-five Per Cent. If they ask for information-even if they are not in accordance with the forms and traditions of the Housethen, where we can help the opposition, we are prepared to provide information. I made it clear just a couple of minutes into the long tirade of the Leader of the Opposition that we could provide the information he sought. But, no, this Leader of the Opposition would rather fume, thunder and fret on his feet for 20 minutes than receive the information he claims to be interested in. He wanted to let off steam in this House rather than receive the information he claimed to want. The fact is that he can thunder, fume and fret in this House all he likes. It will not save his leadership. Ms Gillard-I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. It has to work both ways. I would ask that the Leader of the House be brought back to the dissent motion. It is about the standing orders. A reference to House of Representatives Practice might be in order.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS
text: Yesterday the member for Corio asked me to confirm that Primary Energy Pty Ltd had sought funding through the Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program for its ethanol project in Gwydir in the first half of 2003, and then he asked why the government had failed to support this project under its Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. I undertook to get some information from the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, and I can inform the House that Primary Energy Pty Ltd did not submit any applications for funding for any round of the Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. They did register an expression of interest in relation to the third round, but they did not submit any applications. Consequently, there was no rejection by the government of their applications and, furthermore, the Leader of the Opposition's subsequent question was based on an entirely false premise; it was utterly empty and without foundation. Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: On 2 December 2004 the member for Lingiari asked a series of questions related to the visit to Parliament House on that day by Mr Michael Long. I am advised that at about 10.05 a.m. on 2 December 2004 Mr Michael Long and a number of supporters approached the Australian Federal Police Protective Service officers stationed on the forecourt of Parliament House to request permission to have photographs taken. The AFPPS officers involved agreed to the request and photographs of the group were taken as they stood on the mosaic. Mr Long's group then indicated they wished to use an Aboriginal flag as a backdrop for the photographs. At this point, the AFPPS officer advised the group the most appropriate place for a photograph involving a flag or banners would be on Federation Mall. The group acknowledged this advice, indicated they were unaware of the protocols surrounding protests or demonstrations and readily agreed to relocate to the southern of Federation Mall. The AFP officers walked and chatted with Mr Long's group as they walked towards Federation Mall. Photographs with the flag were taken on Federation Mall with Parliament House in the background. As far as the AFPPS officers were aware, no-one in the group was offended by the AFPPS action, and the AFPPS received no indication from members of the group that any apology was necessary. Ms Gillard-On indulgence, Mr Speaker. The member of Lingiari is absent from the House today due to some personal circumstances. With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, he might want to raise that issue with you again when he returns to the House. I just do not want you to have the impression that there may be no further questions about it because of the member for Lingiari's absence.

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I have a number of questions to you. During the course of question time today, I could not help but notice that on this side of the the microphone levels seemed to be at a different intensity to those on the government side. I know this may sound funny to some government members, but I actually had trouble hearing what the Leader of the Opposition was saying. I conferred with some of my colleagues, and during that discourse the Leader of the House stood up and the levels were distinctly louder. I ask if you could investigate that. In addition, when the member for O'Connor apparently rose on a point of orend der, as the member for O'Connor stood, the microphone came on before you had even recognised him and it became evident that the member was getting a glass of water, not raising a point of order. I ask if you could investigate and report back to the House on that situation as well. Also, on a number of occasions when the Leader of the Opposition actually did have the call, rose to his feet and came to the dispatch box the microphone did not come on. You had recognised him, but the microphone did not come on for some time, and it made it very difficult on this side to hear what the Leader of the Opposition was saying. Finally, when the member for Grayndler rose to the dispatch box and you had properly recognised him, again the microphone did not come on until quite some time after you had recognised him, yet the microphone went on for the Leader of the House without him having the call. I am seeking some explanation from you as to how the system works; I am not sure. If you could investigate and report back to the House, I would appreciate it.
