Speaker: Mr NAIRN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I move: That the House do now adjourn. Australian Institute of Sport

Speaker: Mr GRIFFIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I recently attended the Australian Institute of Sport with the Minister for the Arts and Sport, Senator Rod Kemp, to see the undertaking of the development of the new pool and other facilities that are part of the redevelopment that is occurring at the AIS. The new facilities are going to be at the very cutting edge of sporting facilities. The aquatic centre that is there will provide a new pool and other facilities which will really give our athletes a chance to realise their capacities and ambitions into the future. Construction will occur over the next 15 to 18 months, as I understand. It will involve a pool which, as I said earlier, will be at the very cutting edge of technology. It will have the capacity for camera work so that it can be clearly understood what the swimmers are doing under the water. There will be a range of other facilities-areas to deal with injuries and other aspects-which will really give them a chance to move ahead. It certainly is an example of what can and should be done to try to give our elite sportspeople the chance to improve on the results that they have achieved in recent times. Members would know that at Athens we had an incredibly impressive result right across a range of sports. We certainly can be very proud of what our athletes achieved. Petria Thomas, the Olympic gold medallist, was there and spoke on the occasion. She certainly recounted some interesting tales of her time at the AIS. To all those involved with the new facilities, I wish them all the best with those developments. It was certainly a pleasure to be there representing the federal opposition. I hope to go along there in the future to see the completed facility and the other facilities that are part of the redevelopment. It is part of what has provided our athletes with the opportunity to realise their abilities and their ambitions and I would urge all members, if they get a chance, to go out there and have a bit of a look at what is going on at the AIS. It is very impressive, and it is something that we can all be very proud of. Bass Electorate: Trail of the Tin Dragon

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House a project of great importance to Northern Tasmania, that being the proposed project known as the Trail of the Tin Dragon. The Trail of the Tin Dragon is a local themed touring trail within the north-east touring route. Its aim is to attract and connect visitors to the region through stories of the Chinese and the tin mining industry in north-east Tasmania. The trail fits within the north-east touring route and this has the potential to increase the number of visitors travelling between Launceston and St Helens by 60,000 per year and to add up to around $9 million each year to the regional economy. In addition to the tourism benefits, the project could potentially drive needed infrastructure development, build the social capital of the community and help establish better cultural and economic links with modernday China. Chinese tin miners were amongst the early pioneers of Tasmania's north-east and were the largest group of non-European immigrants to early Tasmania. Their arrival commenced in the late 1870s and at their peak they numbered around 1,000. The history of these people is closely tied to the tunes of the state's tin mining industry. Their ingenious mining skills and business acumen played an important role in the development of the region and Tasmania. The stories of the people and this time are a point of difference for north-east Tasmania and part of our nation's cultural heritage. The remaining evidence and personal associations with the Chinese of this time are, however, disappearing. The Trail of the Tin Dragon is guided by memories and stories, community passion for the history of the place and an emphasis on Tasmania's core appeals of cultural heritage, natural experiences and the region's food and wine. The work done so far has been preliminary. No-one has been a stronger supporter for this project than me and so I was delighted that the Prime Minister, on 27 August this year, pledged real Australian government support. The government provided $50,000 to the Dorset Council to undertake a business development plan for the tourist project. On the successful completion of this business plan, and subject to the project being viable, the government is prepared to provide up to $1.7 million towards the development of the project. The steering committee has now appointed the Sentience Group to carry out the business plan. This will be led by Bob Campbell, Lynda Jones and Brian Green. This, of course, is a critical stage; the group must demonstrate the viability of the project in the tourism marketplace to qualify for the $1.7 million, and I certainly wish them every success. When complete the Trail of the Tin Dragon will see sites, stories, photographs and artefacts of the people and the time brought together with infrastructure, services and interpretation to create a better sense of place and a memorable visitor experience. It will benefit a part of Tasmania where the fortourism product and associated infrastructure could do with enhancement. From a national perspective, the trail will interpret a significant part of our Chinese cultural heritage and provide modern-day links with China through a potential sister city relationship with the immigrants' province of origin. In fact the establishment of this relationship has been a contribution that I have been able to make, by coming up with the concept earlier in the year and progressing negotiations with the Chinese Embassy here in Australia. Finally, I would like to mention the contribution made over the last weekend by the Hobart based Tantra Buddhism group who travelled up to Scottsdale to help the local community celebrate the Dorset Christmas parade. In their own way this group added their moral support to the project and provided what can only be described as a very colourful and energetic display of a Chinese dragon for all to enjoy. Of course, the traditions are quite different, but the goodwill and support is very welcome. Aviation: Bankstown Airport

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Blaxland) (10.58 p.m.)In just eight short days, the draft master plan for Bankstown Airport must be handed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Hon. John Anderson. The longcoming day is 15 December. Very early this year, the first indications were given that this master plan would be put into effect. There were three months of public consultations. There was an indication very early on that not all that much would change but, when the preliminary draft master plan emerged, I as the member for Blaxland, representing half of the 165,000 people of Bankstown, in conjunction with Mr Daryl Melham, the member for Banks, was confronted with something completely contrary to my expectations. Firstly, there was a demand that the main runway, 29C, be extended by over 200 metres. Secondly, there was a provision that regular public transport should be introduced into Bankstown Airport. Thirdly, there was no provision whatsoever that large aircraft such as category 3D and category 4C would be forbidden from landing at Bankstown Airport. Consequently, given that all of these things were contrary to our expectations, the member for Banks and I launched a public campaign against these elements of the preliminary draft master plan. I am happy to be able to tell you tonight what I recently announced in my electorate and what has been confirmed by Mr Kim Ellis, the CEO of the Bankstown Airport Corporation, in this week's edition of the Bankstown Express. Following a meeting between me, Mr Ellis and his boss just three days before the election, the indication given was that they would look closely at what I and 4,000 people had argued in individual submissions and form letters that I and the member for Banks had put out. The very first point that we argued for was that there should be an absolutely concrete prohibition on large jet aircraft at Bankstown Airport. That has finally been acceded to by the owners of the Bankstown Airport Corporation. This means that 737s, 717s and the like will not be allowed to land at Bankstown Airport. This means that, in effect, what this government attempted to achieve on 13 December 2000-namely, to turn Bankstown into Sydney's overflow airport-will not be achieved and the new private owners will act not only in their own private interests but also in the community interests of the people of Bankstown. This outcome would not have been achieved without the support of all of those people who signed up to the public campaign run by me and the member for Banks, because the intention in the preliminary draft master plan was to simply say, âFor planning purposes we do not take these things into account.' When pressed by the community organisation that was put together to look at this, the owners initially said that they wanted to reserve all of their options and, in a future with changing technology, they wanted to be able to say that, with a longer runway and regular passenger transport using it, larger aircraft could use the airport. I congratulate Mr Ellis and the owners of Bankstown Airport Corporation on having the good sense to act not only in their interests but also in the broader interests of the Bankstown community. I ask them to do two other things: firstly, to strike out from the draft master plan the extension of the runway by 200 metres; and, secondly, to cast out from that draft master plan the introduction of the regular passenger transport aircraft from Bankstown Airport. Neither of those things are in the interest of the Bankstown Airport Corporation and, as indicated in the preliminary draft master plan, they are certainly not in the interests of the people in the community of Bankstown. We do not want in any shape or form to change the nature of Bankstown Airport as a general aviation airport. We do not want an extension or a change to its operation, and I call for those things to happen. (Time expired) Child Support Agency

Speaker: Mr SCHULTZ
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I once again rise in this place to talk about what I call the national shame that is the Child Support Agency. In my files, I have in excess of 450 case studies from all over Australia with regard to the dreadful way in which men and women are being treated by the Child Support Agency-and they are still coming in. Let me now read from one case study, from a mother of two sons. She says: I am the mother of two sons, one whom is separated with 3 children aged 10, 8 & 6. Over the past five years, my son has taken his responsibility as a separated DAD very seriously-both in supporting his children emotionally and financially. As his ex-wife received 72% of their assets by the Court, their car, and all the contents of their home getting started again has been a nightmare. He currently pays 47% tax and 34% in child, so you can see that there from every dollar he earns. He works 10 days straight, very long hours, including on-call, and is out in all weathers. I believe he is being destroyed by the current child support system and he feels there is very little incentive for him to continue on working in this manner and getting nowhere. I notice that his personality has changed and that he is becoming increasingly anxious and depressed about his situation. I am very worried about him. However, what makes me really mad is that my grandson tells me about their mother and her new partner's three investment properties, their very large new home, their new car, and plasma t.v all this while my husband is in the kitchen sticking the soles of their shoes back on with superglue! Clothes are cast offs from others and what is sent down in the bag is nothing short of disgusting. It is left to me to buy pyjamas and other clothing items, as well as providing extra money for food and entertainment when they come to stay for the school holidays. I feel this situation is very wrong and that there should be some accountability about how maintenance money is spent. I am sure that I am not alone and that many grandparents are helping their sons the same way I have to. I would be interested to know in this climate of political largesse with public funds what tangible support is to be given to separated DADS-not the Dead beat DADs that people so often use to label them. Elizabeth Andrews I also now very briefly quote from another email I received, this one from a 70-year-old constituent of mine. He said: I am 70 years old in good health and I have worked hard all my life, taught in TAFE (Business) for 30 years, wrote 22 books for the students and started a network of Tax & Accounting offices in the last 15 years which numbered 22 at its high point-third largest in Australia. I am aware of your terrible accident which you have had to overcome, and, for the record when I now work with the pool I go very carefully with the chemicals. I am also a victim of the Child Support Agency. A precis of my CSA Matter. I have supported my twin girls since 1991 (now 17), and never missed a payment in all of that is very little left time, not one! I have been messed about by the staff at CSA for the last few years, they have sent me other peoples files, they have taken on average 80 days to answer correspondence. They have taken my tax refunds, they have taken my interest from the bank, they have made the most obvious mistakes and often not corrected them. When I took over the care and custody of one of the twins, they INCREASED my payments under the support scheme, and, then refused to reduce same! I wont go on you have seen it before-is there a minister or assistant that I can put this matter I have told this particular individual that there is, as I have told many such people. I have answered every email that has come to me, because I have a real concern as a member of parliament about the way in which the Child Support Agency in this country is operating and about the way successive governments and ministers of the Crown have allowed this to happen. They are killing males; they are sending males into institutions because they are having mental breakdowns. If something is not done about it we are going to have what can only be described as a catastrophe in the area of male health because of the pressure that is being put on them by the Child Support Agency. I intend to read as many of these case studies as I can over the next 12 months until such time as I bring the responsible ministers of the Crown to their knees and make them-forcibly, if I have to-do something about changing the culture and about removing the legislation that is obviously not being followed by the Child Support Agency with the best intentions of supporting children, as it was supposed to. This is not a Child Support Agency issue. It is now an issue centred on how much money and how many assets the payee gets from the payer. (Time expired) Economy: Performance

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Prospect) (11.09 p.m.)Tonight I want to address some important issues for the people of Prospect and for the people of many other electorates in relation to economic management and to place on record some comparative figures with respect to economic indicators for various governments. During the last election campaign the government made all sorts of claims about its economic management. It ran very hard on interest rates. Everywhere to? you turned, you saw television and newspaper advertisements from the government spruiking that it was a superior economic manager and that interest rates would rise under a Labor government. The government campaigned on economic growth. Its television advertisements talked about 8Â½ years of uninterrupted economic growth. That is accurate. I take no issue with that. But there have been more than 8Â½ years economic growth. There have been 13 years of uninterrupted economic growth. If you looked at the advertisements, you would have thought that economic growth started miraculously in 1996. We have had consistent economic growth since 1991. But of course it goes further than that: economic growth under the Hawke and Keating governments averaged 3.7 per cent per annum whereas average growth under the Howard government has been 3.6 per cent per annum. These rates are similar, but the rate was higher under the Hawke and Keating governments. This would normally simply be a matter of historical interest, but the government made a lot of play on the fact that interest rates were higher under the Whitlam, Hawke and Keating Labor governments compared to what they have been whilst they have been in office. If they are going to start raising historical comparisons going back to 1972, the ledger has to be clear. All economic figures need to be compared and economic growth has been higher under previous Labor governments than it has been under this government. We all know that the matter of interest rates was a key issue in the election campaign. Again, the government advertised extensively, saying that interest rates had reached over 10 per cent under every Labor government since 1972. What those advertisements did not point out is that the official cash rate under the Fraser government was also over 10 per cent. The Treasurer at that time was none other than the honourable member for Bennelong. I think it is important to put these figures on the record, because economic management will be a key area of debate over the next three years and will certainly be a matter of keen interest for the people of Prospect. In the recent election campaign the Labor opposition had savings and reprioritisations to pay for its election commitments. The government did not. The government's economic policies are placing more pressure on interest rates and it will be very interesting see what happens to interest rates over the next three years. I certainly hope, on behalf of all the people who have heavy mortgages, that interest rates do not increase. One thing the government is right about is that a small increase in interest rates will have a big impact on members of the community. In 1996 the average mortgage in New South Wales was $118,000. Today that figure stands at $255,000. I will also deal briefly with the Howard government's management of the current account, a key economic indicator. The current account deficit is now as big as it has ever been. Exports are underperforming dramatically. However, the government cannot blame the terms of trade. The terms of trade indicate the value of goods that we export compared to the value of our imports. The terms of trade are not in the control of the government. Currently, the terms of trade are at 113.4, compared to 86.0 in December 1985. In the last current account crisis that this nation faced we had a terms of trade crisis. Today we face a current account crisis with our terms of trade figures the best they have ever been. The government are running out of excuses when it comes to economic management. They ran in the election campaign as being the better economic managers, but they are really becoming the emperor without clothes. We will be holding them to account over the next three years for their very poor economic management. They have overseen a reduction in investment in research and development and have taken a very ordinary approach in developing our elaborately transformed manufactures, which are the key to improving our export growth. While we have an economy which is continuing to rely on goods other than elaborately transformed manufactures, we are going to see a current to account deficit like the one that this government and this Prime Minister and Treasurer have been overseeing and we are going to continue to see the economy go down the perilous path it has been going down in recent weeks. Indi Electorate: Citizen of the Year Award

Speaker: Ms PANOPOULOS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: A few months after my inaugural election I instigated an award open to all people in my electorate, the Indi Citizen of the Year award. I created the Indi Citizen of the Year award to provide an opportunity for people of north-east Victoria to celebrate the achievement and contribution of a local resident and to recognise a resident who could be a role model for all of us, particularly one who had not received formal recognition for their voluntary contribution to their local community. In my job, not a day goes past where I do not meet someone or hear of someone making an extraordinary contribution to the local community and through creating this annual award I was hoping to provide an avenue for us to identify and formally recognise, on an annual basis, an individual who has made a significant positive impact on my electorate of Indi. Selfreliance, self-help, personal sacrifice, reachhill. ing out to others, looking out for your neighbour and community works are true hallmarks of the people of the north-east. Those are the collective qualities that give enduring strength to the fabric that binds country communities together. It is this very spirit upon which the Indi Citizen of the Year award is based. Last year I was delighted to present the Indi Citizen of the Year award to Wangaratta resident Margot Ballard. Tonight I have great pleasure in declaring Helen Bird, a resident of Whitfield in the beautiful King Valley, the recipient of the 2003-04 Indi Citizen of the Year award. Helen is an absolute champion of the Whitfield community. She is secretary of the local Red Cross; she is heavily involved in the Greta Craft Group-one of the most effective women's support groups in the whole of north-east Victoria-she is secretary of the local golf club, which includes many of the menial jobs that not many others are prepared to undertake; she assists at the Whitfield Public School through helping young students with literacy programs and teaching them how to improve their literacy skills; and she displays a compassionate advocacy for the town's elderly residents and assists at the local community health centre in this regard. One resident of Whitfield told me that Helen is the glue that binds the community together and that she is a person who is always there to lend a hand, but never seeks to be thanked or rewarded. Without even knowing or realising it, Helen has done all she has for the local Whitfield community not for deeds or bouquets that may come her way but by striving, in the words of Ben Chifley in his famous 1949 âLight on the Hill' speech, for âthe betterment of mankind, not only here but anywhere we may give a helping hand'. Within the small Whitfield community, Helen Bird is one such light on the Without people like Helen Bird doing their bit for the people around them, rural communities will wither and die. It is no secret that the rate of volunteerism in rural communities is much higher than that found in the cities. Be it in the army of volunteer groups such as Rotary and Lions clubs, the Red Cross and other welfare organisations, the CFA and the SES, it is here where the true spirit of rural communities is found. Often within these groups are found true examples of community spirit. Helen Bird is such an example. I thank and commend Helen for the commitment and effort she gives to her local community in the beautiful King Valley. Whether it is a family crisis or a small personal problem, residents of Whitfield and the surrounding area know that they have a friend and an ally in Helen Bird, who will help to look after them. Tonight it is my great pleasure to officially award the 2003-04 Indi Citizen of the Year award to Whitfield resident Helen Bird. From the depths of my heart, thank you very much, Helen, for the work you have done for your fellow citizens in the King Valley. Education: Vocational and Technical Education

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Cunningham) (11.18 p.m.)Yesterday during question time the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education displayed quite extraordinary arrogance and, indeed, ignorance, all in the space of less than two minutes. This minister clearly shoots from the hip. In the Australian Financial Review on 30 November, the minister is quoted as pushing a particular company in the Illawarra as a possible interested party in the establishment of one of the government's proposed technical colleges. The problem is, of course, that the company knows nothing about this. It was a classic case of a new minister simply shooting from the hip on the issue, and yesterday in question time the minister confirmed that he was doing just that. This is what the minister told the Australian Financial Review on 30 November in a report titled âBusiness forced to fund training': I don't want to put any pressure on any people, but you may end up with a BlueScope Steel boilermakers college in the Illawarra ... Not surprisingly, this immediately attracted my attention. The minister claimed yesterday in answer to a question from me that he did not see the Australian Financial Review report. BlueScope Steel certainly saw the report and responded to my inquiries very clearly, saying that BlueScope has: ... not been able to ascertain that we have any formal discussions with the government about setting up a training college. That was the BlueScope response to me when I made inquiries of the company last Tuesday. The minister simply has no idea what is happening in the Illawarra to address the skills shortage crisis. Instead, he makes the claim that since the Howard government was elected in 1996 apprenticeships have increased by 202 per cent in my electorate. No, not an increase of 20 or 50 or 60 or even 80 per cent but 202 per cent since 1996. I will certainly be asking the minister to both fully detail and verify this claim in the future. That 202 per cent figure is certainly a mysteryas my colleague the member for Throsby would confirm-to businesses, trade unions, TAFE and other training organisations in Wollongong and the Illawarra. The Howard government has in fact ignored the growing skills crisis in Australia, and particularly in regions like ours, for the past eight years. Now it has dreamt up an inadequate and flawed response by establishing these technical colleges, one of which will apparently be located in the Illawarra. Where? We do not know, although I suspect it is more likely to be in a government held electorate in our area. Labor have been warning of this skills shortage crisis for a long time. We did it in the last parliament and I remember the discussions in the parliament prior to that. During the campaign I worked closely with the member for Throsby and our shadow minister at the time, the member for Grayndler, in talking to local groups. We had many meetings with them and raised the issue on many occasions. Last week the Illawarra Regional Development Board released a phase 1 report on the skills shortage in the Illawarra. It is a very compelling report. Perhaps the minbeen in ister would like to read it carefully. Aside from this recent report, local businesses, unions, TAFE, the University of Wollongong, training companies and regional development stakeholders have been actively talking about issues and pursuing innovations to address the skills shortage in our region. In the supplement in the Illawarra Mercury today there was an overview of what has been and still is taking place in the region to address the skills shortage in the Illawarra. There are pilot programs under way, auspiced by the Illawarra Business Chamber. The area consultative committee has gone to the length of establishing a skills shortage task force. We are dealing cooperatively with all the stakeholders involved. Instead of leadership, this minister-who I doubt has ever even visited our region-has displayed arrogance about what is happening in the Illawarra. He trumpets the 202 per cent figure. The minister should be aware that there is offence taken at this approach in my region when we are working so hard to seriously address the issue.  TAFE.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Indeed. They cannot get into TAFE, and businesses cannot find apprentices. They are not creating skills task forces and developing major reports funded by local organisations in order to address a phantom problem. The minister should recognise this. The minister should stop speaking about our region in a flippant and ill-informed manner. On 1 April-and I acknowledge it was April Fools' Day- (Time expired) Road Safety

Speaker: Dr JENSEN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to address the issue of Australia's road safety performance in the last 10 years. This is basically the period since very harsh speed enforcement has become standard policy in the states. The states generally trumpet harsh speed enforcement for reducing the fatality rate on our roads. The reality, however, is that you need to have a look at the trend of Australia's road safety performance and contrast this with the OECD median. On that basis, we are doing relatively worse than we were 10 years ago. In other words, the fatality rate decrease that Australia has seen in the last 10 years has been less than the fatality rate decrease that has been noted in the OECD average. It is quite interesting to note that one of the scientists at the Monash University Accident Research Centre, Stuart Newstead, did a very comprehensive evaluation of the crashworthiness of cars. He found that, if you examine the improvement in crashworthiness between 1970 and 2000, two-thirds of the fatality rate reduction can be explained purely in the improved crashworthiness of cars. This does not consider improvements to the roads themselves. It does not consider improvements to cars' handling and braking capabilities or improvements in driver training that have taken place since then. This has to make you wonder about the value of the rigid speed enforcement policies that have been undertaken. The states Australia wide have used the results of a study by Kloeden and MCLean of the University of Adelaide. Their claim is that, for every five kilometre an hour increase above the speed limit, there is a doubling in the risk of a casualty crash. The simple fact is that this study has numerous significant faults. I have gone through the research report myself, and there are numerous procedural errors in the methodology used. Also, Minister Haermeyer of Victoria has claimed that recent speed camera versus speed radar tests that were undertaken show that the speed radar is three kilometres out in many cases. Mr Haermeyer makes the point that the speed cameras were fine when measured in the laboratory. Mr Haermeyer, the fact is that the real world is significantly different from the laboratory. For example, if cars are not travelling exactly parallel to the laneways then you will get an erroneous result. You also have factors such as radar scintillation which can cause erroneous results. Ministers need to accept these real-world errors. Another interesting factor that has come up-and this really demonstrates the need for improved driver training-is that the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety in the United States did an evaluation of vehicles fitted with electronic stability controls, and found that the fatality rate in vehicles so fitted was 35 per cent lower than in vehicles without. This clearly indicates that there is potential to improve the fatality rate by 35 per cent by having improved driver training, because drivers will be able to use adequate skills to avoid crashes, rather than, in many cases, not having the skills and having crashes. In terms of road safety, we must make sure we measure what is important and not make important what we can measure. Speaker: Election  Speaker, I do not have much time but I do wish to convey to you formally my great pleasure in your elevation as Speaker. It is a great honour to be Speaker of this House. You follow a number of your predecessors from a distinguished career on committees. I have in mind in particular the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, where you served long and honourably and were held in affection by those committee members. Mr Speaker, I know that the job you have is a very important one because you have to uphold the rights and privileges of all members of parliament-especially backbenchers-but I would like to say that you occupy your high office with my best wishes and, I know, overwhelmingly, those of many of my colleagues. I would like to offer you my sincerest congratulations on your high office. Question agreed to.
